data.text: Is Komoot a Good Navigation and Route Planning Software?
Does anyone use Komoot for navigation and route planning? Is it a good option?
We found it a good option! You can use it without internet and tells you pretty much all you need to know? You can select the type of terrain you wanna ride on too.
data.author: Malibé Contreras

data.text: It’s the best. I plan my trips on my desktop, they appear automatically on my phone. Option to offline use while navigating and make changes on the road.
data.author: Joeri Erregeerts

data.text: I enjoy it. Love getting other people's routes and trying them out
data.author: Stephen Harrison

data.text: Yes. Works mostly fine
data.author: Karel Castelein

data.text: Yes, works, I use it daily. Most missed feature to have satelitte map while navigation, switching sattelite - regular map
data.author: Vaidotas Pe

data.text: It's tried sending down private road and tracks too often, don't trust it anymore
data.author: Paul Eaves

data.text: , Google Maps does that too. Frustrating.
data.author: Phil Joyce

data.text: it not the app but the quality of the OSM. And who had updated the area,
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: either way it's an issue
data.author: Paul Eaves

data.text: I use it and it works great for me, especially integrated with Garmin. I’d suggest that you try it on the free region that you get, and if you like it, consider unlocking the navigation in the whole world with a single payment, if that option is still offered. That seems better than the Premium subscription - although you might want to try Premium for a year and decide later.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: yes, I like that indent have to have a premium subscription to use maps
data.author: Jason Underwood

data.text:
If I wasn't already paying OS Maps, I might consider it. https://www.komoot.com/features
Komoot’s Features | The Best Outdoor Tech
komoot.com
data.author: Phil Joyce

data.text: I wish.. I didn't have time to learn it and GPS was really messing with me.
data.author: Leslie Carvery

data.text: Works ok but can send you down some really bad tracks. I used it on a recent trip across France and found it was best to have it on the phone as well as you get a big overview of what’s coming up as Komoot will often send you in a big u around a town adding a couple of miles instead of actually going through the town on better roads, it’s great some time but not when you want groceries etc
data.author: Andy Warner

data.text: spot on analysis.
data.author: Andy Dennis

data.text: Probably true of any of these apps. But if just nipping down the shops, then Google maps will do the trick. The problem with tracks is that they are not surveyed on the ground, the same as any road. You can expect a range of surface quality. I have been down some really horrible paved roads, full of pot holes and cracks. I have been down some really smooth gravel tracks. Some tracks get rutted and muddy in the rain, but if there is a lot of cars and trucks using it, the rut get smashed flat when it dries out again. If there are not many cars then rutted tracks stay rutted.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I have used Komoot but have found even in road bike mode it sends you up tracks that are suitable for gravel tyres or even mtb tyres. I use Ride with GPS most of the time. It chooses decent routes and is easy to customise. Sending routes over to Wahoo or Garmin is quick and simple.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text:
Personally I use it for navigation, but prefer cycle.travel for planning a route, faster and not so many surprises a komoot. https://velotouring.fun/review-cycle-travel
Review cycle.travel
velotouring.fun
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text: Like , cycle.travel for planning, gpx downloaded and then re-uploaded to RideWithGPS which automatically syncs to my Wahoo. I really dislike Komoot for its inability to add to or edit routes, but if others like it, that’s great.
data.author: Matt Kemp

data.text: thanks, I’ll take a look
data.author: Jason Underwood

data.text: I‘m using Komoot since a while for planning bike trips on gravel or road bike. I guess it works quite good. Sometimes you end on tracks that are not rideable. But you can check the surface of the planned route in the app. I got komoot premium which includes better card material that even show most bike paths. So yeah, i would recommend it.
data.author: Simon Desch

data.text: Yes though it's not perfect. They usually have offers to upgrade from one region to all if you wait round long enough. bad- you can only see ncn routes on the desktop, not the mobile version without going premium...good- they now have Google streetview to see what the 'road' looks like ..as others have said some of the bike touring routes aren't suitable for gravel bikes let alone touring or road bikes...
data.author: Ben Williams

data.text: I like it a lot. Komoot tracks are synced to my Suunto watch where I can follow the tract.
data.author: Bračko Davor

data.text: I really don’t like it. Clunky, and route planning is very flawed (no undo option, weird routing, some weird paths) I wish it just added the points I’m adding in the order I do it - like footpath does
data.author: Kay Anky JS

data.text: Have a look at cycle.travel. so easy to convert GPX on your phone.
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: Just checked out cycle.travel. It's great! Too bad they don't have an app. I think I'll use it to plan the route, then export the gpx file to Komoot.
data.author: Jason Underwood

data.text: An iPhone app is currently under development, fyi. An Android app will apparently follow after that 👍
data.author: Stuart Cormie

data.text: Great news!
data.author: Jason Underwood

data.text: Jason they do have an app. Well sort of. It's not on the App store. Open the Web page on your phone then go to the 3 dots at top RH side. From menu. ' Add to home screen' and there you have it. You might have to rename it. Everything you do on your PC will then appear on mobile phone. It's so easy for planning routes. I then download to App, GPX viewer Pro for offline use. This is how it looks.
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: I wouldn’t fully trust the route finding in bike touring mode as I have experienced some very dubious cycle ways. However, the road cycling route choices seem to try and keep you off the busiest roads and have been reliable for me.
data.author: Martin Clark

data.text: can be a bit glitchy and occaionally sends you down some innaprpropriate lanes / tracks, but overall I have to say it's been a game changer for me. The best bit is you can steal bits of other peoples' routes and plan your own also according to highlights other people have pointed out.
data.author: Akāshamitra Tuyuguv

data.text: Cycle travel for planning and Wahoo, Komoot or OsmAnd for navigation. You can easy create or adapt your track on your phone and send it to the navigation app.
data.author: Wim Lintermans

data.text: I use Komoot for gravel riding & RWGPS for the road. I don't find Komoot very good for road routes, but it's good for off-road. It's got no idea about the off road conditions, so it might be a muddy path or perfect gravel road. I'd still use it though.
data.author: Andrew Weaver

data.text: I use it. It can be quite optimistic tho.. yes, you can ride a bike here! Me: noo!
data.author: Patricia Larsson

data.text: I’m currently cycling from Scotland to Lithuania and I’m having no problems using it. Komoot took me through the streets with very little noise pollution. Not sure how it works outside Europe though.
data.author: Justas Juozaitis

data.text: Quite good
data.author: Jan Ayalin

data.text: Quite nice
data.author: Shanthom Bld

data.text: They always want my money and don't let me download gpx for free. Synchronization with Wahoo not easy.
data.author: Our Man InChad

data.text: I use EasyRoute
data.author: Fred Rufener

data.text: Yes, works great but do check the route before setting off. Sometimes it routes a longer distance than necessary and also misses off road bits which are nicer than going on the road.
data.author: Nathan Molyneaux

data.text: The touring mode takes you off road where possible? Unless it's strictly mountain bike only?
data.author: Damian Thomas

data.text: it does a little, but we are both taking mountain bike trails here more a bit of gravel or hard packed mud
data.author: Nathan Molyneaux

data.text: Yes. It's about right for my Nomad - even took us on a trail over the peaks that a seasoned mountain biker was surprised to see us fully loaded on!
data.author: Damian Thomas

data.text: I rather experienced the opposite. Komoot constantly wants to lead me to obviously hiking trails (not possible to cycle), or rough gravel, when I put cycling (not mountainbiking) as the activity. And there would be a asphalt road very close that would be perfectly fine to cycle.
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner

data.text: there is a road bike activity as well which might give you better results
data.author: Nathan Molyneaux

data.text: nope, tried that out, leads me to the same trails ;-)
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner

data.text: for example in Italy, Komoot led me here
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner
Wulfram Georg Tanner
Wulfram Georg Tanner
Wulfram Georg Tanner

data.text: You can choose if you will follow the road and you can see if there are unpaved and gravel roads included. You can easily change the route, if you don't like it.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: What did you choose? Hiking?
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: No, of course cycling. The plain normal cycling. Not MTB or anything. 😅 And I checked, if choosing road biking, it still picks that trail. And that is not the only place where Komoot does these things. There should be an option to exclude all these thin black trails; they are almost always not suitable for a travelling bike. Or an option to always favour (asphalted) roads assuming it is allowed to cycle there.
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner

data.text: agree
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: I did coast to coast and it tried to take us off track to accommodation - obviously the route of someone who had used said accommodation. Also, had a few instances of 'Make a U turn' going on for ages, when we had taken a slight detour, or faster route, but were still en route and fine - it didn't adjust route. Still really useful. Also used it useful locally and found some good little tracks that I didn't know of.
data.author: Damian Thomas

data.text: We've used it around Lake Constance this week. Spot on 👍
data.author: Gary Charlton

data.text: Thanks everyone. I got the discounted wold map. I like that I don't need a monthly subscription to plan routes. The only problem is they don't have regions for Australia, which is where I'm headed soon. Support said I can plan the route and that section of map will download, so should still be ok.
data.author: Jason Underwood

data.text: I crossed Sweden, part of Denmark using it, no problems at all. It could detect on what side of the street bicycle lane is. I was planning with my mobile phone, sometimes opened downloaded gpx files with komoot app, added or deleted some points. After planning on app was done, shared phone wifi with garmin edge and komoot route appeared on garmin instantly.
data.author: Jonas Duoba

data.text: I like komoot, but it has taken me to some rather difficult paths from time to time. It can easily be avoided by checking rural parts the route on satellite maps before heading out 😃
data.author: Søren Rosenius Olsen

data.text: I learned to read maps, in the boy scouts,,,
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: I can read paper maps as well, but it is too heavy to carry all the maps I would need with me. It also takes time off cycling. I walk, go by bicycle, did drive my car - in unknown areas with Google maps. Actually I use Komoot now.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Im Older, I Now have a collection of international maps of Europe, I biught alon the way & when done mailed them back to the states.. * 91 into eastern Europe right after the Warsaw pact dissolved & 97 I was in Scotland when Diana & Dodi were in that car crash in Paris. my camera used film. that did not keep me home...
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: basically what is so great about komoot. vs just talking to locals?
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: IMO the bestone
data.author: Karotq VonPlumke

data.text: We use it a lot for planning on our Amazing World Bike Tour Since it uses a lot of juice we don't use it while riding though. But on the computer with open cycle map it is a fantastic planning tool! If you can recharge your phone every day anyways navigation is also good 👍
data.author: Mathias Kissling

data.text: Works for me.
data.author: Amad Doratotaj

data.text: Plot a komoot route on laptop (in conjunction with looking at google maps street view)and sync to smartphone for use offline..never had an issue
data.author: Dave Hux

data.text: I used it on a hike in the states the other day and it was so helpful.
data.author: Carrielynn O'Reilly

data.text: Yes I think it's good,but some minor details to improve
data.author: 霸特

data.text: - have you chimed in?
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: Have some great features but misses som very basic and very useful features. Above all, you can't save a place as a bookmark, you need another app for that. So you need to enter addresses you use a lot every single time, for instance your home adress. This is so basic that I almost couldn't believe customer service when they confirmed that this wasn't possible, even for a premium subscriber like me. Also - if you are at A and want to plan a trip from B to C in mobile app, it is SUPER wonky. Mine gets it right 1 out of 10 times and I have to be super meticulous. So no, I wouldn't recommend it, unfortunately.
data.author: Mikkel Ørstedholm

data.text: I use it along with many other apps I don't rely on anyone in and of itself commode is good for recording rides. Most apps I find don't want to take a route like I try to get it to do they try to use the straightest quickest and put you on highways in such instead of the more interesting twisty Country Roads that is why most people like to use a pre-planned touring map from one of the groups that offer such things
data.author: Craig Cartner

data.text: I also use it, in most cases it is perfect. However sometimes it fails miserably and sends you down roads forbidden for bikes, or really small technical trails, even tho you selected the roadbike option.
data.author: Sandra Peters

data.text: I planned my upcoming long distance route on komoot - the premium version, because it shows the EuroVelo and other bicycle routes, but it was complicated to get komoot to follow the routes. I had to put in a lot of "ending points", though the overview looks like this (see the screen shot below). The route is split in 100 days. I couldn't download the gps-file for the entire route. It is only possible for 1 day at a time. I tried the navigation as well (for much shorter routes) and that works fine. Sometimes, when I try to get a route it is too complicated and long, that I use Google maps instead.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: To be fair a 100 day tour will always be difficult to plan. I think Komoot is the best route planning tool out there but it's probably unrealistic to expect not having to tweak the routes Komoot suggests out of the box. I'm fine with that. I like to plan my routes very meticulously by using quiet roads and Komoot provides all the tools to do so. If you want a quick set and forget option I think the resulting route will always be subpar. Edit: One important thing to note is that Komoot should always be used in a desktop browser. The mobile route planning in the app is way too basic for anything but the most simple tours.
data.author: Michael Feihstel

data.text: Thanks, I did max 1 w at a time and put all in a collection. That was the only way my smartphone didn't crash.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Yep it’s good but it drains the battery 🪫🫤
data.author: Mike Daniels

data.text: Excellent - works well
data.author: Pernille Tiedemann

data.text: I use Komoot. It's very interesting to see how the route options change when switching from road to touring to gravel to mountain biking. If I am familiar with an area it's easy to make tweaks to the Komoot first draft. It's also useful when routing between locations with which I am not familiar or for routing an out and back loop. There was only one instance where Komoot gave me an impassable route segment but it wasn't too hard to navigate the old fashioned way to get me back on track.
data.author: Anthony Medina

data.text: Love it!!
data.author: Dwynn K Landry

data.text: All GPS stuff does weird things sometimes because they all rely on the same map info, which is not always correct. Regard it as advice, nothing more, make your own decisions.
data.author: Dave Binks

data.text: We used it cycling across the US last summer. Very useful app
data.author: Julianna Henley

data.text: I use Komoot since 5 years! It’s the best GPS App. I payed for the premium version so I can use the maps worldwide and it’s worth it !
data.author: Maria-Theresia Von Seidlein

data.text: .... ALWAYS use classic paper maps ...
data.author: Alessandro Eboli

data.text: How often do you need to recharge your smartphone if you use Komoot?
data.author: Alan Kimber

data.text: if you download and go to airplane mode I made my Samsung last 3 days.
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text: To add to that, you need to buy the map pack (it is a one time payment of ca. 20€ for the whole world). Then you can save tours for offline use and you can download regional maps and access them in the planning mode. Strangely, even if you downloaded the map and the tour, you cannot do any changes to it, like adding another waypoint, which is annoying.
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner
